awd_titl_txt: OP: MRI: Development of a Visible Wavelength Extreme Adaptive Optics Coronagraphic Imager for the 6.5 meter Magellan Telescope
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award will allow a team of astronomers at the University of Arizona to construct a state-of-the-art instrument for use at the 6.5 meter Magellan telescope in Chile.  This instrument will permit direct imaging of faint planets and debris disks around bright stars.  Several postdoctoral fellows and graduate students will play key roles in the design and testing phases.  The instrument will enable a wide range of science for a large number of astronomers at member institutions as well as their collaborators from outside the consortium.   It will push the envelope of adaptive optics capability, which will have a major positive impact for a wide range of scientific and commercial applications.

This University of Arizona team will develop world-leading capabilities in high-contrast coronagraphic adaptive optics imaging and spectroscopy through a new instrument to be developed for the 6.5 meter Magellan telescope in Chile.  The instrument will extend adaptive optics capabilities into the visual band, enabling unique science capabilities, especially for imaging exoplanets and proto-planetary disks.  The MagAO-X instrument will build incrementally on the current MagAO system and through three carefully-considered stages, ultimately leading to a new comprehensive instrument. This MRI development effort will enhance infrastructure and provide sorely-needed training opportunities for future instrumentalists.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled the design and construction of the Magellan Adaptive Optics Extreme instrument, MagAO-X, to study extrasolar planets and conduct other high-resolution and high-contrast astrophysics investigations.  Adaptive Optics is a technique used to correct images blurred by atmospheric turbulence, which is the reason stars twinkle.  This is done by measuring the amount that light was distorted by the turbulence with a wavefront sensor and applying a shape to a deformable mirror to correct the distortion, in effect "de-twinkling" the starlight.  For ground-based telescopes this process is necessary to enable high spatial resolution, that is how close one object (like a star) can be to another and still be observed.  Adaptive optics is also necessary to enable high contrast, that is observing faint objects (like a planet) next to a much brighter object (like a star).


MagAO-X uses a 2040 actuator deformable mirror, and a wavefront sensor which can run as fast as 3600 images per second to deal with rapidly changing turbulence.  Together, these powerful devices allow exquisite images to be obtained from the 6.5 meter (21.3 ft) diameter Clay telescope at Las Campanas Observatory in Chile.  MagAO-X also includes a coronagraph, which is a device for blocking the bright glare from a star, allowing astronomers to study much fainter planets orbiting that star.


MagAO-X was constructed at the University of Arizona.  Much of the work was performed by students in the Department of Astronomy and in the College of Optical Sciences at UArizona, including 9 undergraduates and 15 graduate students.  Almost all of these students helped install and commission MagAO-X on the Clay telescope in Chile. These students were involved in all aspects of the project, and received hands-on training in optical and mechanical design, electronics and software, and system engineering.  


MagAO-X is now fully operational and astronomers from around the U.S. are using MagAO-X for their investigations. Early results include confirmation of a new star orbiting a much brighter star, discovery of a jet of hot gas being emitted from a young star, the highest resolution images of disks of dust orbiting nearby stars, and extensive studies of very young extrasolar planets still in the process of forming their atmospheres.


MagAO-X also continues to serve as a test platform for the Giant Magellan Telescope (GMT), which is part of the US Extremely Large Telescope (US-ELT) program.  US-ELT was the number one priority in the recent Astro2020 decadal report.  MagAO-X is testing technologies for the GMT and a planned instrument for the GMT called GMagAO-X.  These tests occur both in the lab and at the telescope, and will ensure that the US-ELT program can meet the priorities set forth by the Astro2020 decadal report.
